body:
# Problem:
- Some servers like LuaLS add unwanted blank lines after multiline `@param` description.
    - LuaLS bug: https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/issues/2333
- List items do not wrap nicely.

# Solution:
- When rendering the LSP doc hover, remove blank lines (except in the main description).
- Set 'breakindent'.


## before/after

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/25a4f93c-0773-4fdc-a758-b2883b63c08e)

comment_regular_data.body:
Removing unwanted blank lines is nice. But personally, I somehow like empty lines before `@param`, `@return`, etc. so they are clearly separated: e.g.
```diff
 @*param* `buffer` — Buffer handle, or 0 for current buffer 
+                                                                            
 @*param* `send_buffer` — True if the initial notification should contain the
  whole buffer: first notification will be `nvim_buf_lines_event`.
  Else the first notification will be `nvim_buf_changedtick_event`.
  Not for Lua callbacks.
+                                                                            
 @*param* `opts` — Optional parameters.
 - on_lines: Lua callback invoked on change.
 ...
 - preview: also attach to command preview (i.e. 'inccommand')
   events.
+                                                                            
 @*return* — False if attach failed (invalid parameter, or buffer isn't loaded);
  otherwise True. 
```
Would that be possible without making `split_lines` too complicated?

> personally, I somehow like empty lines before `@param`, `@return`, etc. so they are clearly separated: e.g.

That is a quirk of LuaLS (edit: tsserver also does it. hmm...). Clangd doesn't do this.

Anyway, the latest push implements your request.

@mfussenegger This logic should be harmless for non-LuaLS cases, but I will revert/adjust if we find any problems (I tested clangd/tsserver/lua). This is also temporary until https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/issues/2333 is fixed.

This also added some test coverage :)

Hmm I personally dislike hacks like this one that accommodate a misbehaving server. I also thought that one of the goals of #25073 was to simplify the markdown rendering of these floating windows and preventing this kind of modifications to the markup content.

> one of the goals of #25073 was to simplify the markdown rendering of these floating windows and preventing this kind of modifications to the markup content.

This doesn't conflict with that though. Markdown has no requirement (in terms of readability) that blank lines be preserved.

The fact is, different servers add (luals) or remove (clangd) blank lines in random places. We're the presentation layer, why shouldn't we have a consistent display of the `@param` fields?

I don't like hacks, but,
- we've been suffering from this bug for 1+ years
- this hack is generalized, it's not specific to a server (except the assumption of `@x` annotations)
- this is easy to revert
- it's covered by tests (this behavior had no coverage before now)

Do we want to live with this bug? Is there an alternative? Why is the old `split_lines` acceptable but the new one isn't (specifically, which parts)?

> * we've been suffering from this bug for 1+ years

Well then maybe let's contribute the fix upstream? As mentioned in https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/issues/2333, the bug is reproducible outside neovim. Do we want all editors to create a fix like this one? Why use LSP at that point?

> * it's covered by tests (this behavior had no coverage before now)

I don't see why this is an argument in favor of the change. Of course I won't complain about adding a test, but I don't see why we need to test this particular broken case.

> Do we want to live with this bug? Is there an alternative? Why is the old split_lines acceptable but the new one isn't (specifically, which parts)?

I understand where you're coming from, but I try to maintain the general goal of "let's stick to the LSP and only the LSP" that we have all been trying to follow (you have even corrected me in previous PRs when our roles were reversed!). If a language server sends us broken markdown, I believe that we should not do anything to it and display it as is.

> contribute the fix upstream? As mentioned in [LuaLS/lua-language-server#2333](https://github.com/LuaLS/lua-language-server/issues/2333), the bug is reproducible outside neovim.

Even if that bug is fixed, "normalizing" empty/blank lines is something that will forever be needed, it's a general issue. This is a *presentation layer* decision, there is nothing in the LSP spec or markdown, spiritually or technically, that says we must show identical whitespace in our hover. Especially for TUIs, whitespace is how we do layout.

> , "normalizing" empty/blank lines is something that will forever be needed, it's a general issue. 

Normalizing blank linkes to fit the markdown definition of a paragraph would be fine, what's to me problematic is the assumption of a specific layout for `hover` and the `^ ?%@.?[pr]` handling. That's language specific and has no special meaning in markdown

> specific layout for `hover` and the `^ ?%@.?[pr]` handling

Yes, my rationalizations were flimsy.

Avoiding server-specific hacks in our client is our strategy for maintainability, so that we don't have an unhappy, buggy mess. Delegating to markdown as in #25073 is high-leverage. 

But if we've exhausted that path and can optimize presentation/UX with a low-risk, test-covered, isolated hack, let's be open to that.

I'm still open to reverting this, but can we wait to see if it causes a problem?
